Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the mother needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Story: I stare at the blinking cursor on my screen, headset pressing into my ears, the hum of voices in the call center blending with the anxious thrum in my chest. As a mother, I know the home loan repayment is looming—just two months away. Every call I make, every sale, is a step toward keeping our home secure. I need this job, need to meet my targets, need to keep the paychecks coming. But as a telemarketer, I’m expected to take my scheduled breaks, to log off exactly when I’m supposed to, even though the phone queue never empties. Management watches every minute, every click, and I can’t afford to draw attention by breaking the rules. My phone buzzes with a message from my son’s school—he’s sick, and they need me to pick him up. My break isn’t for another hour. My heart pounds as I weigh the expectations: the mother who must be there for her child, the employee who must not risk her job. I grip the mouse, torn, the pressure mounting as the next call flashes on my screen.
